A hands-on guide to exploring the moon's schedule on this special day, honored on Friday, October 10, 2025.

The much-anticipated moon on Karwa Chauth typically graces the sky late in the evening. This isn't mere chance but part of a stunning cosmic harmony. The timing is influenced by the moon's orbit, its celestial position, and where we stand on Earth.
Karwa Chauth occurs on the fourth day (Chaturthi) of the moon's waning phase (Krishna Paksha), with moonrise happening later in the evening as it's just four days after the full moon.
The moon appears about 50 minutes later daily, so by the fourth waning night, its rise is much delayed compared to the full moon.
The moon's rise time varies by city because its appearance over the horizon is dictated by your exact latitude and longitude on Earth.
